## 1 -- Credibility Crisis

- "Why most published research findings are false" [@ioannidis2005most]
- Psychology has lion share of bias/misleading results [@simmons2011] 
- Science: Serious concern about robustness of results
  - 100 studies replicated, about 36% produced statistically significant results [@open2015estimating]

## 1 -- Solutions -- Currently

- Proposed solutions: 
  - Go beyond null hypothesis testing, switch to CIs <span style="color:green"> ✔︎ </span>
  - Open Data <span style="color:green">✔︎</span>, Shared code<span style="color:red"> ✗</span> 
  - Open Access publishing <span style="color:green"> ✔︎ </span> 
  - Engage in study **replication**

- Meta-research [@hardwicke2019a] concludes
  - Journal data sharing policies have improved the situation
  - We neglect these principles in practice [@hardwicke2019]

## 3 -- Solutions?

- Increasingly engage in replication

  - Part of training of MA, PhDs, and postdocs
  - Integrate to teaching: Year 2 replication projects (5th year now) [https://musicscience.net/durms/](https://musicscience.net/durms/)

- Replication Networks in psychology
  - [https://www.ukrn.org](https://www.ukrn.org), [Many Labs](https://osf.io/wx7ck/), [Psychological Science Accelerator (PSA)](https://psysciacc.org)

- Our own **Music Research Replication Network**? (better name, principles, commitment)
